Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enhancing and Expanding Experiential Learning Modules across Disciplines and Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the adaptation, implementation, and dissemination of best practices in experiential learning in the core middle years of the engineering curriculum where students take the bulk of technical fundamentals. The study will involve two series of junior-year fundamental core engineering courses; one taught at Northwestern University's Department of Biomedical Engineering and other at University of Florida's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. The course sequences use similar tools and teach similar topics geared towards building skills needed for success in the engineering workplace or graduate school. The differences are in methods of delivery and the types of experiential learning modules employed.

Using a mixed method approach, the main goals of this proposal are to 1) assess each course sequence in terms of How People Learn and assess how student experiences and outcomes are linked to those attributes of each course and 2) enhance and expand effective experiential learning modules for broader adoption and implementation. The project will evaluate student learning preferences, student engagement, retention of material in subsequent courses in their respective sequences, transferrable skills between courses and learning of course concepts. Both schools have highly selective engineering programs, but the student demographics differ. These differences give the opportunity to consider more demographic factors in assessing the courses and in designing materials to take advantage of diversity. The knowledge will guide future design or development of new interventions and their dissemination strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

This exploratory collaborative project between University of Florida and Northwestern University supported the implementation and adaptation of a new class that primarily relies on experiential learning. Specifically, the project focused on a one semetser course development at University of Florida's Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering that formed a new Breadth course option for ECE students with background in circuits, signals and systems, modeling, instrumentation) that are geared towards building quantitative and computational skills needed to understand biological systems. The course employ portable lab kit (Digilent Analog Discovery Scope) at University of Florida that can be set up anywhere on a laptop.

The key activities consisted of: 1) assessing the strengths and weaknesses of the course in terms of the How People Learn (HPL) framework and assessing how student experiences and outcomes are linked to those attributes of the course; and 2) expanding experiential modules for broader adoption and implementation, possibly in another class to be developed for more advanced concepts (Currently the PI teaches another class entitled Neural Signals, Systems and Technology that does not have a lab component, so it is aniticpated that the project outcome will contribute to such class).

With the data collected from the course, we were able to lay the groundwork for developing an experiental learning module that complement the theoretical aspect of class lecture. 

Broader Impact:

Successfully completed a lecture+lab based content for teaching ECE students the basic principles of biological systems. Future publications are planned. We expect our developments and findings to contribute to the advancement of ECE teaching tracks for students interested in combining quantitative and computaitnal skills with basic principles of life sciences.
